remixlab.proscene

Class Scene

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.fpstiming.AnimatorObject
      • remixlab.dandelion.core.AbstractScene
        • remixlab.proscene.Scene
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    PConstants, Grabber, Animator

    public class Scene
extends AbstractScene
implements PConstants
    A 2D or 3D interactive Processing Scene with a profile() instance which allows Shortcut to Method bindings high-level customization (see all the *Binding*() methods). The Scene is a specialization of the AbstractScene, providing an interface between Dandelion and Processing.

    Usage

    To use a Scene you have three choices:
    1. Direct instantiation. In this case you should instantiate your own Scene object at the PApplet.setup() function. See the example BasicUse.
    2. Inheritance. In this case, once you declare a Scene derived class, you should implement AbstractScene.proscenium() which defines the objects in your scene. Just make sure to define the PApplet.draw() method, even if it's empty. See the example AlternativeUse.
    3. External draw handler registration. In addition, you can even declare an external drawing method and then register it at the Scene with addGraphicsHandler(Object, String). That method should return void and have one single Scene parameter. This strategy may be useful when there are multiple viewers sharing the same drawing code. See the example StandardCamera.

    Interactivity mechanisms

    ProScene provides powerful interactivity mechanisms allowing a wide range of scene setups ranging from very simple to complex ones. For convenience, two interaction mechanisms are provided by default: AbstractScene.keyboardAgent(), and AbstractScene.motionAgent() (which in the desktop version of proscene defaults to a mouseAgent()):
    1. The default keyboard agent provides shortcuts to InteractiveFrames and scene keyboard actions (such as AbstractScene.drawGrid() or AbstractScene.drawAxes()). See AbstractScene.keyboardAgent().
    2. The default mouse agent provides high-level methods to manage the Eye and InteractiveFrame motion actions. Please refer to the MouseAgent and KeyAgent API's.

    Animation mechanisms

    ProScene provides three animation mechanisms to define how your scene evolves over time:
    1. Overriding the Dandelion AnimatorObject.animate() method. In this case, once you declare a Scene derived class, you should implement AnimatorObject.animate() which defines how your scene objects evolve over time. See the example Animation.
    2. By checking if the Dandelion AbstractScene's AnimatorObject.timer() was triggered within the frame. See the example Flock.
    3. External animation handler registration. In addition (not being part of Dandelion), you can also declare an external animation method and then register it at the Scene with addAnimationHandler(Object, String). That method should return void and have one single Scene parameter. See the example AnimationHandler.

    Scene frames

    Each scene has a collection of InteractiveFrames (see frames()). An InteractiveFrame is a high level Frame PSshape wrapper (a coordinate system related to a PShape or an arbitrary graphics procedure) which may be manipulated by any Agent) and for which the scene implements a 'ray-picking' with a color buffer technique for easy and precise object selection (see pickingBuffer() and drawFrames(PGraphics)).

      • Scene

        public Scene(PApplet p,
             PGraphics pg,
             int x,
             int y)
        Main constructor defining a left-handed Processing compatible Scene. Calls AbstractScene.setMatrixHelper(MatrixHelper) using a customized MatrixHelper depending on the pg type (see Java2DMatrixHelper and GLMatrixHelper). The constructor instantiates the AbstractScene.inputHandler() and the AnimatorObject.timingHandler(), sets the AXIS and GRID visual hint flags, instantiates the AbstractScene.eye() (a Camera if the Scene is3D() or a Window if the Scene AbstractScene.is2D()). It also instantiates the AbstractScene.keyboardAgent() and the mouseAgent(), and finally calls AbstractScene.init().

        An off-screen Processing Scene is defined if pg != p.g. In this case the x and y parameters define the position of the upper-left corner where the off-screen Scene is expected to be displayed, e.g., for instance with a call to Processing the image(img, x, y) function. If pg == p.g) (which defines an on-screen Scene, see also AbstractScene.isOffscreen()), the values of x and y are meaningless (both are set to 0 to be taken as dummy values).

        See Also:
        AbstractScene.AbstractScene(), Scene(PApplet), Scene(PApplet, PGraphics)

      • pApplet

      • pg

        public PGraphics pg()
        Returns the PGraphics instance this Scene is related to. It may be the PApplets one, if the Scene is on-screen or an user-defined if the Scene AbstractScene.isOffscreen().

      • pixelDepth

        public float pixelDepth(Point pixel)
        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Returns the depth (z-value) of the object under the pixel.

        The z-value ranges in [0..1] (near and far plane respectively). In 3D Note that this value is not a linear interpolation between Camera.zNear() and Camera.zFar(); z = zFar() / (zFar() - zNear()) * (1.0f - zNear() / z'); where z' is the distance from the point you project to the camera, along the Camera.viewDirection(). See the gluUnProject man page for details.

        Specified by:
        pixelDepth in class AbstractScene

      • disableDepthTest

        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Disables z-buffer.
        Specified by:
        disableDepthTest in class AbstractScene

        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Enables z-buffer.
        Specified by:
        enableDepthTest in class AbstractScene

      • pre

        public void pre()
        Paint method which is called just before your PApplet.draw() method. Simply calls AbstractScene.preDraw(). This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it.

        If AbstractScene.isOffscreen() does nothing.

        If pg() is resized then (re)sets the scene width() and height(), and calls Eye.setScreenWidthAndHeight(int, int).

        See Also:
        draw(), AbstractScene.preDraw(), postDraw(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), AbstractScene.isOffscreen()

      • draw

        public void draw()
        Paint method which is called just after your PApplet.draw() method. Simply calls postDraw(). This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it.

        If AbstractScene.isOffscreen() does nothing.

        See Also:
        pre(), AbstractScene.preDraw(), postDraw(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), AbstractScene.isOffscreen()

      • beginDraw

        public void beginDraw()
        Only if the Scene AbstractScene.isOffscreen(). This method should be called just after the pg() beginDraw() method. Simply calls AbstractScene.preDraw() .

        If pg() is resized then (re)sets the scene width() and height(), and calls Eye.setScreenWidthAndHeight(int, int).

        See Also:
        draw(), AbstractScene.preDraw(), postDraw(), pre(), endDraw(), AbstractScene.isOffscreen()

      • endDraw

        public void endDraw()
        Only if the Scene AbstractScene.isOffscreen(). This method should be called just before pg() endDraw() method. Simply calls postDraw().
        See Also:
        draw(), AbstractScene.preDraw(), postDraw(), beginDraw(), pre(), AbstractScene.isOffscreen()

      • postDraw

        public void postDraw()
        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Called after your main drawing, e.g., P5.draw().

        Calls:

        1. TimingHandler.handle()
        2. InputHandler.handle()
        3. AbstractScene.proscenium()
        4. AbstractScene.invokeGraphicsHandler()
        5. AbstractScene.displayVisualHints().
        Overrides:
        postDraw in class AbstractScene
        See Also:
        AbstractScene.proscenium(), AbstractScene.invokeGraphicsHandler(), AbstractScene.gridVisualHint(), AbstractScene.visualHints()

      • frames

        public ArrayList<InteractiveFrame> frames()
        Returns the collection of interactive frames the scene handles.

      • branch

        public ArrayList<InteractiveFrame> branch(GenericFrame frame)
        Collects frame and all its descendant frames. When eyeframes is true eye-frames will also be collected. Note that for a frame to be collected it must be reachable.
        See Also:
        AbstractScene.isFrameReachable(GenericFrame)

      • drawFrames

        public void drawFrames()
        Draw all scene frames() into the pg() buffer. A similar (but slightly less efficient) effect may be achieved with for (InteractiveFrame frame : frames()) frame.draw(pg());.

        Note that drawFrames() is typically called from within your sketch pApplet() draw() loop.

        This method is implementing by simply calling AbstractScene.traverseGraph().

        See Also:
        frames(), pg(), drawFrames(PGraphics), InteractiveFrame.draw(PGraphics)

      • drawFrames

        public void drawFrames(PGraphics pgraphics)
        Draw all frames() into the given pgraphics. No pgraphics.beginDraw()/endDraw() calls take place. This method allows shader chaining.

        Note that drawFrames(pickingBuffer()) (which enables 'picking' of the frames using a 'ray-picking' technique is called by postDraw().

        Parameters:
        pgraphics -
        See Also:
        frames(), drawFrames(), InteractiveFrame.draw(PGraphics)

      • matrixHelper

        public MatrixHelper matrixHelper(PGraphics pgraphics)
        Returns a new matrix helper for the given pgraphics. Rarely needed.

        Note that the current scene matrix helper may be retrieved by AbstractScene.matrixHelper() .

        See Also:
        AbstractScene.matrixHelper(), AbstractScene.setMatrixHelper(MatrixHelper), drawFrames(), drawFrames(PGraphics), applyWorldTransformation(PGraphics, Frame)

      • bindMatrices

        public void bindMatrices(PGraphics pgraphics)
        Same as matrixHelper(pgraphics).bind(false). Set the pgraphics matrices by calling MatrixHelper.loadProjection(boolean) and MatrixHelper.loadModelView(boolean) (only makes sense when pg() is different than pgraphics).

        This method doesn't perform any computation, but simple retrieve the current matrices whose actual computation has been updated in AbstractScene.preDraw().

      • applyTransformation

        public void applyTransformation(PGraphics pgraphics,
                                Frame frame)
        Apply the local transformation defined by the given frame on the given pgraphics. This method doesn't call bindMatrices(PGraphics) which should be called manually (only makes sense when pg() is different than pgraphics). Needed by applyWorldTransformation(PGraphics, Frame).
        See Also:
        applyWorldTransformation(PGraphics, Frame), bindMatrices(PGraphics)

      • applyWorldTransformation

        public void applyWorldTransformation(PGraphics pgraphics,
                                     Frame frame)
        Apply the global transformation defined by the given frame on the given pgraphics. This method doesn't call bindMatrices(PGraphics) which should be called manually (only makes sense when pg() is different than pgraphics). Needed by InteractiveFrame.draw(PGraphics)
        See Also:
        InteractiveFrame.draw(PGraphics), applyTransformation(PGraphics, Frame), bindMatrices(PGraphics)

      • drawEye

        public void drawEye(Eye eye)
        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Draws a representation of the eye in the scene.

        The near and far planes are drawn as quads, the frustum is drawn using lines and the camera up vector is represented by an arrow to disambiguate the drawing.

        Note: The drawing of a Scene's own Scene.camera() should not be visible, but may create artifacts due to numerical imprecisions.

        Specified by:
        drawEye in class AbstractScene

      • drawEye

        public void drawEye(PGraphics pg,
                    Eye eye)
        Implementation of drawEye(Eye).

        Note that if eye.scene()).pg() == pg this method has not effect at all.

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(KeyFrameInterpolator kfi,
                     int mask,
                     int nbFrames,
                     float scale)
        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Draws the path used to interpolate the KeyFrameInterpolator.frame()

        mask controls what is drawn: If ( (mask & 1) != 0 ), the position path is drawn. If ( (mask & 2) != 0 ), a camera representation is regularly drawn and if ( (mask & 4) != 0 ), oriented axes are regularly drawn. Examples:

        drawPath(); // Simply draws the interpolation path
        drawPath(3); // Draws path and cameras
        drawPath(5); // Draws path and axes

        In the case where camera or axes are drawn, nbFrames controls the number of objects (axes or camera) drawn between two successive keyFrames. When nbFrames = 1, only the path KeyFrames are drawn. nbFrames = 2 also draws the intermediate orientation, etc. The maximum value is 30. nbFrames should divide 30 so that an object is drawn for each KeyFrame. Default value is 6.

        scale controls the scaling of the camera and axes drawing. A value of AbstractScene.radius() should give good results.

        Specified by:
        drawPath in class AbstractScene

      • drawCross

        public void drawCross(float px,
                      float py,
                      float size)
        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Draws a cross on the screen centered under pixel (px, py), and edge of size size.

        Specified by:

      • drawTorusSolenoid

      • setDefaultKeyBindings

        public void setDefaultKeyBindings()
        Calls removeKeyBindings() and sets the default frame key bindings which may be queried with info().

      • profile

        public Profile profile()
        Returns the frame Profile instance.

      • setProfile

        Sets the scene Profile instance. Note that the Profile.grabber() object should equals this scene.

        setBindings(Scene)
